replies.context: To say the wolves came first is meaningless. Wolf populations come and go on this island. Inbreeding will quickly destroy the present population and after a while, new wolves will come from the mainland over the frozen lake. Now, of course, men will totally interfere with the natural patterns but that's what men do. It's not like wolves are going to go extinct.

Inbreeding for this population won't be a problem, because, if you read the article, there is the option of bringing in new wolves, or they might come naturally. FarkQuark explained that quite nicely as well.

That said, I doubt that inbreeding was the cause of the reduced number of wolves, as per the article. That would take a LOT longer than a decade for it to be a problem, unless they had been isolated on the island for a long time before the decade of decline, which seems unlikely.

BTW, wolves were threatened with extinction not long ago, and were on the IUCN Red list.

If I were to guess, I'd say the wolves left the same way they came. It's likely they come and go regularly. Of course, Man will find it necessary to interfere with the natural order. It's what Man does, which is okay if there is a good reason but even for no reason men will interfere. It's what they do.
